Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multiphoton Microscope for Biomaterials Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
MRI: Acquisition of a Multiphoton Microscope for Biomaterials Studies

Nontechnical explanation of the project's broader significance.

An outstanding feature of multiphoton microscopy is its ability to simultaneously map chemical and structural information on the submicron length scale. The Brandeis multiphoton microscope is being used to elucidate the mechanisms of protein crystallization, to control protein aggregation for pharmaceutical applications and to develop novel condensed phases of proteins for drug delivery, all problems of significant scientific and industrial importance. Students rotate through the microscopy facility where they are trained on this state-of-the-art equipment. More broadly, this instrument has become part of the NSF Materials Research Facilities Network and therefore is available to materials science researchers nationally.

Technical description of the project.
This multiphoton microscope provides high resolution optical images using multiple contrast methods; second harmonic generation, 2- and 3-photon excitation fluorescence microscopy, fluorescence lifetime imaging, FÃ¶rster resonance energy transfer and fluorescence correlation spectroscopy. The high power laser is also being used to affect the sample, for example, to induce protein crystal nucleation, to perform laser ablation of microtubules and muscles and to perform 3D printing. Studies underway at Brandeis include (1) protein crystal nucleation, (2) active matter structure, (3) membrane organization, (4) spliceosome assembly and (5) filament assembly in vivo. No other single instrument has the capability to perform this ensemble of measurements, combined with the ability to probe and measure the response on submicron length-scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MRI acquisition consists of a tunable, pulsed Ti:Sapphire laser, electronics and optics for fluorescence lifetime imaging incorporated into a commercial optical microscope platform. This multiphoton microscope will provide high resolution optical images using multiple contrast methods. “Multiphoton” refers to generation of signal by the simultaneous interaction of two or more photons with the sample leading to emission of light, either via scattering or by fluorescence. Multiphoton processes require high intensity; to achieve this excitation is confined to a small focal spot with a high NA lens. For protein samples, the fluorophores can either be endogenous, or added as fluorescent labels. The majority of proteins contain some fluorescent amino acids with tryptophan generating the largest signal.

To understand biomaterials, it is necessary to characterize both molecular composition and arrangement. One outstanding feature of the multiphoton microscope is its ability to simultaneously map chemical and structural information on the submicron length scale. The chemical information provided by the multiphoton microscope includes the identity, concentration and local environment of molecules, while the structural information reveals positional ordering of molecules. An additional feature is the ability to locally perturb the sample and measure the effect on the chemistry and structure.

The acquisition of the multiphoton microscope is producing knowledge that will be used to improve the success rate of protein crystallization for structural biology, to control protein aggregation for pharmaceutical applications and to develop novel condensed phases of proteins for applications of drug delivery, problems of significant scientific and industrial importance. Additionally, the microscope is contributing to the fledgling field of Active Matter research, through elucidating the mechanism by which extensile microtubule bundles exert force and generate motion.
